GridUseCaseScenario.Name: Integrated Volt/VAR Regulation in the Low Voltage (LV) Distribution Network with High Distributed Energy Resource (DER)
GridUseCaseScenario.Overview: Integrated Volt/VAR Regulation in the distribution grid is supported through an Integrated Volt/VAR controller (IVVC) which is an integral part of distribution feeder and distribution operational SCADA. IVVC allows grid operators to closely monitor and control the voltage and power factor of the grid in a centralized or decentralized manner. Also, the IVVC supports Volt/VAR Optimization (VVO), which increases the transmission efficiency of the existing grid by allowing grid operators to reduce transmission losses through VAR optimization. As we know, the extent of DER installations are expected to increase in the years to come. Thus, the need for voltage regulation in the LV distribution network will also increase. At the same time, more smart meters are installed at customer locations, providing more information to support voltage regulation. This use cases describe the voltage and power factor control functionality in LV distribution networks using integrated volt/VAR control strategies with high penetration DER.
GridUseCaseScenario.Description: Normally, voltage control is essential for utility companies to ensure that the voltage being supplied to consumers is within an acceptable range. Any deviations from this acceptable range can damage the appliances and electric equipment of consumers. Also, utility companies use VAR regulation methods to ensure that the power factor ratio remains close to 1, meaning nearly all real power to avoid power factor penalties for customers. Maintaining the power factor near to 1, reduce power losses to utilities and increase transmission efficiency too.. Traditionally, the voltage profile and reactive power flow on a distribution feeder are controlled independently and by the transformer tap-changers (TPC), capacitor banks (CB), voltage regulators (VR), static synchronous compensators (STATCOM), static var compensators (SVC), and battery energy storage systems (BESS). Conventional VVC algorithms in the DMS or distribution remote terminal units (RTUs) are designed for controlling the on/off states of the capacitor banks at the feeder circuits and distribution substations, the substation transformer taps positions, and the voltage regulator taps at the feeder circuits, all in binary or discrete quantities. With the recent integration of microgrid and DER, the voltage and reactive power flow in the LV distribution network fluctuate more in term of faster and variance than before and require continuous adjustment within certain ranges. Sometimes, it was observed that adjusting VAR at one point/location can negatively impact the voltage level at a different point/location. This arrangement will introduce new challenges to VVC algorithms because they must handle mixed control variables, some in binary and others in continuous (adjustable) quantities. Additionally, the smart meters periodically send data every 15 minutes to warn of registered low/high voltages. This smart meter alarm/warn data can be useful for utilities when they want to regulate voltage profile and reactive power flow. Integrated volt/VAR technologies and systems provide new capabilities for grid operations to automate voltage controls and reactive power management. IVVC uses a two-way communications network to coordinate the volt/VAR control actions amongst various control devices to regulate VAR without affecting the voltage. IVVC offers several benefits including higher visibility into system operating parameters, reduced emissions of greenhouse gases, and increased transmission efficiency.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Capacitor Bank is Closed into Load
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder capacitor bank is commanded to close the circuit breaker of the capacitor onto the LV distribution network. This capacitor will provide capacitive reactive power and neutralize the inductive reactive power generated in the system due to inductive load. In this way, the power factor of the distribution network will improve.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Capacitor Bank is Opened out of Load
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder capacitor bank is commanded to open the circuit breaker of the capacitor from the LV distribution network. This reduces the capacitive reactive power and thus reduces the power factor.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Capacitor Bank Configuration
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder capacitor bank is commanded to configure its setting. Noted that capacitor banks are designed with many configurations to meet system design constraints. How much VAR should the capacitor bank supported is determined through the bank configuration.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Regulator Configuration
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder regulator is commanded to configure its solid-state voltage-sensing circuit (VSC) setting. This new configuration maintains the fixed output voltage, irrespective of changes to the input voltage or load conditions.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Regulator Step-Down Command
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder regulator is commanded to step down its VSC setting to lower the LV distribution network voltage. This step-down command is issued when the grid voltage exceeds nominal voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Regulator Step-Up Command
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder regulator is commanded to step up its VSC setting to higher the LV distribution network voltage. This step-up command is issued when the grid voltage is lower than the nominal voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Sensor Configuration
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder regulator is commanded to step up its VSC setting to higher the LV distribution network voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Switch is Commanded to Close
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder switch is commanded to close its circuit breaker to maintain the grid voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Switch is Commanded to Open
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, feeder switch is commanded to open its circuit breaker to maintain the grid voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Switch Configuration
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: Feeder Switch have multiple switching operations. In this scenario, feeder switch is commanded to change its operation setting based on the LV distribution network voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Feeder Recloser Configuration
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: Just like feeder switch, feeder reclosure also have multiple operations to set the grid isolator in its position. This isolator isolates the faulty section of the substation and maintains grid voltage. In this scenario, the feeder recloser is commanded to configure its isolator setting to maintain grid voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Distributed Customer Storage
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, the distribution automation controller (DAC) sends the dispatch command to Dist.Cust storage for supporting voltage.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Initiate Distribution Customer Generation
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: In this scenario, the distribution automation controller (DAC) sends an initiation command to Dist.Cust generation when voltage support is required.

ApplicationScenario.Name: Smart Meters Warn of Registered Low/High Voltage
ApplicationScenario.Narrative: Smart meters periodically send data every 15 minutes to warn of registered low/high voltages. If DMS identifies a voltage waring from the customer side, it will take action based on the available resource.

Attributes.Value: Feeder Capacitor Bank has performed and sent a close operation acknowledgment.
Feeder Capacitor Bank has performed and sent an open operation acknowledgment.

CommunicationSystemRequirement.Name: VVC-01
CommunicationSystemRequirement.Description: Feeder Cap Bank shall be able to send Feeder Cap Bank close command ACK to DMS.

CommunicationSystemRequirement.Name: VVC-12
CommunicationSystemRequirement.Description: DMS shall be able to send Feeder Cap Bank close command to Distr. SCADA FEP.

Equipment.Name: Distribution Ops
Equipment.Description: Distribution operational center.

Equipment.Name: Distribution
Equipment.Description: The distributors of electricity to and from customers. May also store and generate electricity.

Equipment.Name: Regulator
Equipment.Description: These devices are deployed at critical points within the Distribution network to regulate voltage and providing system telemetry regarding the performance of the electric system.

Equipment.Name: Capacitor Bank
Equipment.Description: An Intelligent Electronic Device that provides electronic analog performance information, status, and fault information. In addition, the device can be remotely controlled to increase the voltage on a given segment of the Distribution network

Equipment.Name: Field Sensor
Equipment.Description: An Intelligent Electronic Device is an integrated microprocessor-based controller that provides electronic digital performance information, status, and fault information.

Equipment.Name: Distribution Customer Storage
Equipment.Description: Distributed Customer Storage is a storage device sized to meet typical distribution substation circuit loads and is typically located at or near a distribution substation or in smaller capacities out in customer/premise neighborhoods.

Equipment.Name: Distribution Customer Generation
Equipment.Description: Distributed Customer Generation is a generation source sized to meet typical distribution substation circuit loads and is typically located at or near a distribution substation.

Equipment.Name: RTU
Equipment.Description: An RTU is a microprocessor-controlled electronic device that interfaces equipments between field device and SCADA. RTU transmit telemetry data and receiving control messages to control connected equipment. This device also supports PID, alarming, filtering, etc.

Equipment.Name: Distributed Storage
Equipment.Description: Storage co-located at the substation.

Equipment.Name: Distributed Generation
Equipment.Description: Generation co-located at the substation.

Equipment.Name: DAC-Ops
Equipment.Description: Distribution Application Control system hosted in a Utilities Regional Operation Center to run a specific Distribution application.

Equipment.Name: DAC-Sub
Equipment.Description: Distribution Application Control system hosted in a Distribution Substation to run a specific Distribution application.

Equipment.Name: Data Aggregation Point
Equipment.Description: This is the Data Aggregation Point on the NAN. It is essentially the point of convergence for all communication between smart grid devices and utility back-office systems. In this specific use case, it captures the information from the 2-way meter, distributed customer storage, and distributed customer generation.

Equipment.Name: 2-Way Meter
Equipment.Description: A bi-directional communication device is used to measure electrical energy usage for residential use.

Equipment.Name: DMS
Equipment.Description: Distribution Management System - A system that monitors, manages and controls the electric distribution system.

Equipment.Name: DERMS
Equipment.Description: Distributed Energy Resources Management System - A system that monitors, manages and controls the DER located on the electric distribution system.

Equipment.Name: LMS
Equipment.Description: Load management system - System that controls load by sending messages directly to the device (e.g., On/Off).

Equipment.Name: Distribution SCADA FEP
Equipment.Description: This device serves as the primary conduit for issuing commands from DMS/SCADA and receiving information from field devices deployed within the Distribution network. FEP stands for Front End Processor.

Equipment.Name: AMI Head-End
Equipment.Description: The AMI head end is responsible for the operation and coordination of AMI system components. It represents the central nervous system of the AMI system.

Equipment.Name: Operational Data Warehouse
Equipment.Description: Utility’s Operational Data Warehouse.

Equipment.Name: IEC CIM Equipment
Equipment.Description: A piece of equipment discovered during parsing of an IEC CIM RDF XML file.
